reply_context.text: baselines don't "come with" a hypothesis class, but experiments do. if you are applying the scientific method, you should be able to formalize your question which in turn defines the hypothesis class. you then tweak baselines to be appropriate to your hypothesis class, not the other way around.

posts.text: baselines don't "come with" a hypothesis class, but experiments do. if you are applying the scientific method, you should be able to formalize your question which in turn defines the hypothesis class. you then tweak baselines to be appropriate to your hypothesis class, not the other way around.

reply_context.text: OK, but baselines do not normally come with a real hypothesis class. Let's say I add a component to my loss function, which also requires me to make my network bigger. posts.text:
no, but you definitely need to separately ablate the change to the learning objective from the change to the model's capacity.

reply_context.text: I think one of the reasons reported baselines are often misleading is because people will put in only enough effort to get them to run at all, resulting in extremely lazy configurations. This is really evident in CV where baselines will always look way worse than the OG papers that introduced them.

posts.text: I think one of the reasons reported baselines are often misleading is because people will put in only enough effort to get them to run at all, resulting in extremely lazy configurations. This is really evident in CV where baselines will always look way worse than the OG papers that introduced them.

reply_context.text:
> People will debate whether you tuned the baselines ‚Äúfairly‚Äù, but over what set?

I think one really straightforward way to look at this is: given how much effort you put into optimizing the configuration of your model, how much effort did you put into tuning the things you compared it against?

posts.text:

reply_context.text: t-sne is more concerned about local than global structure, so if you have a bunch of clusters that are not themselves near each other, t-sne will pull them together just to make it easier to visualize, making it seem like certain clusters are closer to each other than they are.

posts.text: t-sne is more concerned about local than global structure, so if you have a bunch of clusters that are not themselves near each other, t-sne will pull them together just to make it easier to visualize, making it seem like certain clusters are closer to each other than they are.

reply_context.text: add the caveat: "with t-sne". t-sne has a bunch of particular properties that make it more amenable to "always brain" than e.g. a technique like UMAP.

It seems like rather than pushing for more human-in-the-loop practices and more transparency regarding them, you are being critical of the presence of humans in these systems. Which makes me confused about what your desired outcome here is.

reply_context.text: my understanding is that you are taking issue with both the false advertising and with their failure to exclude humans from the loop. The former I can understand, the latter confuses me.

posts.text: my understanding is that you are taking issue with both the false advertising and with their failure to exclude humans from the loop. The former I can understand, the latter confuses me.

reply_context.text: this brings us back to my original contention: if you're of the opinion that human input in these systems is important, it seems counterproductive to me to be vilifying companies for doing it.
